entry.title: Code.org
entry.content:
For the December Houston.pm meeting, Debbie Campbell presents Code.org. The meeting begins on December 12 at 6pm in the Hostgator offices at 5005 Mitchelldale St., Suite 100. We gather in the lobby 30 minutes before.

Do the children in your life have access to computer science education? What does that even mean, and why should you care?

Come find out at HostGator on Thursday, December 12, 6 pm to 8 pm. No prior computer science skills are necessary, and there will be pizza.

You'll experience a nationally vetted K-12 program that's offered in 180 of the United States' largest school districts, as well as private, parochial, and home schools. Did we mention that it's offered at no cost, thanks to generous donors like Microsoft, Amazon, Facebook, and more?

At the least, you'll leave with ideas to entertain holiday visitors of all ages.

About the Presenter - Debbie Campbell, B.S.E.E., M.R.S., is the Rice University School Mathematics Project Code.org program manager. She is also awfully fond of G. Wade Johnson.

entry.title: Notes for 'make-ing a Static Website' posted.

div.p:
G. Wade Johnson has been maintaining the [Houston.pm website](http://houston.pm.org/) for years. The original hosting for the site was located at pm.org and was maintained by volunteers. To reduce their work, they required all hosted sites to be static.
Wade had experience a couple of decades back generating static shells for small amounts of dynamic content. He applied similar techniques to the Houston.pm website to make it easier to maintain.
## A Little History
* He took over maintenance in December 2004 * Originally hosted on the pm.org servers * The pm.org servers only supported static content * Recently began hosting it on servers he controlled * Nov 2002 - mostly empty placeholder * Aug 2003 - meeting schedule announced * Dec 2005 - the first generated version
The site was maintained manually between December 2004 and December 2005.
## Why a Static Site?
Many people have asked why the site is maintained as static HTML, instead of using a more modern framework or tool.
When he first took over the site maintenace, he did not know how long it would last. He did not want to start paying for hosting on something that he might not maintain for long. He figured it would pass to someone else after a few years. Additionally, the site itself had no compelling need for dynamic features. He also was only willing to spend a limited amount of time maintaining it.
At different times in the past, people have recommended converting to a CMS or Wiki to maintain the site. Both of these approaches would require work to convert the content that currently exists and on-going maintenance and security monitoring to keep them functional. Wade is not really interested in generating extra work for himself for dubious benefits.
## Why Generate a Static Site
The first major rewrite of the site (2005) moved to the first version of the generating code.
The main reasons for generating the site are:
* Consistent look/style (such as it is) * Code for creating new pages * Site is under [version control](http://github.com/gwadej/houstonpm/) * Based loosely on the results of his Masters Thesis
Since all of the generating code is in relatively straight-forward Perl 5 code, it should be easy for another maintainer to pick up. If anyone wants to make changes, they are free to send a pull request on github. If a change does not make his life harder, Wade says he will probably accept it.
## The Code
At this point, Wade went to the source on GitHub and began walking through some of the core features.
There are a number generic templates in the [templates/](https://github.com/gwadej/houstonpm/tree/master/templates) directory. Some of these are fragments used by other templates. Others are more or less standalone templates. A number of templates are wrappers defining the general structure of certain pages:
templates/index_wrap.tt2 : the main index page of the site templates/main_wrap.tt2 : any main page besides the index templates/talks_wrap.tt2 : the recent talks and year talks pages templates/writeup_wrap.tt2 : the talk write-up pages
Other core templates include:
templates/copyright.tt2 : specifies the copyright notice on each page, handling appropriate year information and licensing templates/main_menu.tt2 : specifies the left-hand menu for the site templates/recenttalks.tt2 : page listing the most recent talks templates/yeartalks.tt2 : page listing all of the talks for a given year
The whole system is driven by a [Makefile](https://github.com/gwadej/houstonpm/blob/master/Makefile). The Makefile contains quite a bit of redundant information. This turns out not to be a big maintenance problem, because the Makefile is generated from a template ([templates/Makefile.tt2](https://github.com/gwadej/houstonpm/blob/master/templates/Makefile.tt2)).
## Scripts
In the [bin/](https://github.com/gwadej/houstonpm/blob/master/bin/) directory are a set of scripts that Wade uses to build the site. The `bin/talks.pl` script is used to convert the information from the `talks.xml` document into all of the yearly and recent pages. The `bin/announce.pl` script updates the `atom.xml` file which supports feed readers (if anyone still uses them). It also provides the message used to update the mailing list and such when announcing a new meeting. The `bin/writeup.pl` script helps in the construction of the write-ups for each meeting. Among other things, it
* asks the maintainer for information about the talk * creates the appropriate directory structure * leads through writing up the talk * builds a TT file for the write-up
## Legacies
Wade explained that there are some legacy bits due to the length of time this project has run. The `talks.xml` document is basically a database of the talks through time. Since the information is basically a series of short documents, it hasn't been worth any effort to turn it into a more traditional database. Some of the transformation work done to extract data from the talks file is performed through XSL files. This approach has mostly been abandoned, but was a viable system at the turn of the century.
## Conclusion
The audience had a number of questions about particular design decisions. Some of the comments made valid suggestions of other design trade-offs. In the end, many of the decisions made on this system were simply what was easiest at the time.

entry.title: Subtle Magic: Moving to Dancer2/DBIx::Class/TT
entry.content:
The April meeting will be held at HostGator, at 5005 Mitchelldale, Suite #100, Houston, Texas, on April 11. We will meet in the lobby between 5:30pm and 6. Once everyone arrives, we head inside for the meeting at 6pm.

This month, Ruth Holloway will present Subtle Magic: Moving to Dancer2/DBIx::Class/TT.

"Read the documentation", we're told, but there's always more to learn. When I started working with Dancer2, DBIx::Class, and Template Toolkit last fall, I'd seen the basics, but I found out very quickly that there's much more to learn. The capabilities of this stack can influence application design from the ground up database tables, all the way to the final frameworks you might choose to use on the frontend, and not all of those repercussions are immediately clear from merely reading the documentation!

In this talk, we'll learn about some of the strengths of these modules and demonstrate how their capabilities can be leveraged to help you work faster and write great web-based applications.
